ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to code in R and understand single cell biology
learned how to analyze single cell data using R and python and learned how to use HPC software
broad knowledge of sc landscape, how to use analysis pipelines,
I learned a lot about single-cell biology and the different techniques. I also learned about using the cluster and Jupyter notebooks. I've used the cluster before but I did learn new methods for it.
I got a good overview of the field of single-cell biology, its history, and techniques. Also learned the basic overview of various important pipelines and computational approaches.
I learned a lot about single cell biology and about how to use R.

I learned a lot about how to analyze single cell data and how to use R. I honestly learned a lot about coding for bioinformatics which was super interesting and fun! I also learned a lot about single techniques
I learned how to understand and analyze single cell data.

I learned about a variety of techniques in single-cell analysis technologies, including the history of how these technologies were derived as well as their current uses. I also gained an understanding of coding in the HPC and how to use the shell.
Single Cell technology

I learned about many different packages in R and Python related to single cell analysis. Topics included scRNA-seq, cell trajectory analysis, cell-cell communication, CNV and clonal heterogeneity, scATAC-seq, epigenomics, spatial transcriptomics, multi-omics mapping, and imaging-based spatial biology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: good layout
would be improved with more frequent problem sets and/or class participation
I think the assignments (and the github repositories) were great! the labs were also helpful for completing the assignments

A strength of the course is the scope of the material presented and the guest lectures. A weakness of the course is the emphasis on getting through lots of content quickly, compromising the deep understanding of each of the tasks.

I think one weakness was just going through papers every week and not lecture slides. It was sometimes hard to follow. The concepts were all interesting though, and the computational workshops were very helpful.

Strengths: Dr. Fan is a treasure and a sweet guy. Not to mention he is on the forefront of the field and taking his class is a privilege. The class is super chill and you get out what you put in. Super interesting/cutting edge content. 
Weaknesses: Besides the 2 assignments and coding lectures, there is little to force you to be engaged. Many students were in the class to fulfill a requirement with a low workload class, while only a small handful were deeply engaged with the material. The coding labs could also be more hands on.

Strengths: I enjoyed having the guest speakers. The TAs were extremely helpful. The computational labs were great. The papers were interesting. 

Weaknesses: Very disorganized, it was unclear until the final week of the course exactly how grading works.
I enjoyed the papers and the cutting-edge nature of the course. I wish there was more engagement with the coding aspect of it.

This course has a strong balance of lectures on analysis techniques and coding to implement these techniques. This course can be improved with more opportunities for feedback on work or progress throughout the semester.
More assignments; I feel like I did not learn much of anything
Very comprehensive introduction to the single cell field

Strengths: This course covered many topics related to single-cell analysis, and therefore provided a broad overview of the field. The topics selected were also important, since they are currently hot topics in research. We were able to use many powerful packages and even see one that has not been released for public use yet. Weaknesses: There weren't many assignments, so there were few opportunities to practice what we learned in class. Therefore this course relied on self-motivation to get the most out of the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes if you are looking for a BME elective

Yes! The course was super helpful to me in surveying the various methods used in the single-cell realm. Strongly recommend to anyone with/without previous experience in single-cell and interested to learn more.
Yes absolutely. great way to learn about single cell genomics with the pioneer of the field and gain data science skills without an overwhelming workload.

It was very unclear how this course was going to be graded the whole semester and there were only 2 small assignments. It was unclear how participation would be judged so there was no clear feedback mechanism on how to complete the class.
yes - you can learn about single cell research in a low-pressure way.
Yes, it was a great introduction to different single-cell methods, and the workload was very manageable.

Yes, but only if you're truly interested in the content and willing to put in the work to understand what's going on. Unlike other classes, there aren't long coding PSETs or assignments to make sure you read the papers. However, if you do, you'll realize how insanely cool some of these techniques are and how much of an evolving frontier this is. Most of the techniques you learn about have either been developed in the last 10 years or, some of the later ones, are being developed as you learn about them. If you're looking for a super easy blow-off class where you learn nothing, this could also be the class for you although that's a bit disrespectful to the professor.
I would if they are interested in computation.
Absolutely!!
Yes if they are in BME and interested in understanding single cell data.
I would recommend this course to another student because you gain a great understanding of interesting techniques at the forefront of science with a very low course workload.
Yes. Better than any class I take this year.
Comprehensive introduction to single cell technology

Yes! Computational biology is a very hot field in science now, and this course covered many topics that would be very useful in research. As someone who does imaging-based spatial biology, this course was very interesting and helpful to me. The teaching team was also very knowledgeable. Just note that you must be self-motivated to learn to get the most of this course, since there are few assignments to hold you accountable.
Great BME elective to take after a really tough junior year of core classes.
